title-group.article-title: Moisture sorption isotherms and glass transition temperature of elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.) roots at 25°C

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Analytical Chemistry, Faculty of Chemical Technology, University of Pardubice, Pardubice, Czech Republic
2Department of Analysis and Evaluation of Food Quality, Faculty of Food Technology, University of Agriculture, Krakow, Poland
3Department of Engineering and Machinery for Food Industry, Faculty of Food Technology, University of Agriculture, Krakow, Poland

author-notes.corresp: L. Červenka, Department of Analytical Chemistry, Faculty of Chemical Technology, University of Pardubice, Studentská 573, Pardubice 53210, Czech Republic Email: libor.cervenka@seznam.cz

abstract.p: Sorption isotherms of elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.) root samples were obtained at 25 °C. Elecampe exhibited hysteresis loop in the range of 0.35–0.90 aw, whereas burdock roots showed significant differences between adsorption and desorption isotherms from 0.65 to 0.80 aw. Blahovec–Yanniotis was considered to give the best fit over the whole range of aw tested. Various parameters describing the properties of sorbed water derived from GAB, Henderson and Blahovec–Yanniotis models have been discussed. Differential scanning calorimetric method was used to measure the glass transition temperature (Tg) of root samples in relation to water activity. The safe moisture content was determined in 12.01 and 14.96 g/100 g d. b. for burdock and elecampe root samples at 25 °C, respectively. Combining the Tg line with sorption isotherm in one plot, it was found that the glass transition temperature concept overestimated the temperature stability for both root samples.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The knowledge of the moisture content and water activity (aw) relationships of food products is very important. These can be estimated by determining moisture sorption isotherm that is used for defining storage conditions and making shelf-life determination (Mathlouthi, 2001). The unfavorable storage conditions leads to deterioration of the product, which is caused both by native enzymes and by microorganisms’ activity (Ross, 2001). A large amount of data have been published considering the sorption behavior of foods and food products including meat (Singh et al., 2001), cereal products (Turhan et al., 2003) and fruits and vegetables (Falade et al., 2003; Samaniego-Esguerra et al., 1991). Medicinal herbs and spices used in the folk medicine are also in the scope of the interest (Soysal and Öztekin, 2001; Kouhila et al., 2001, 2002).

Elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.), the members of the Compositae (Asteraceae) are used as traditional herbal medicines throughout the world. In the field of medicine, much attention has been paid on the extracts of elecampe due to their antibacterial, antioxidant and antitumor properties (Kang et al., 2003; Spiridonov et al., 2005; Deriu et al., 2008). Anthelmintic and insecticidal effects were also described (Alexenizer and Dorn, 2007; Urban et al., 2008). The chemical composition of genus Inula has been reported in review of Zhao et al. (2006) where various monoterpenes, sesquiterpenes, flavonoids and glycolipides predominates. Burdock roots (A. lappa L.) are rich in inulin-type polysaccharides (Kardošová et al., 2003), which showed prebiotic properties that could promote health (Li et al., 2008). Some new phenolic compounds were recently identified including arctiin, luteolin and quarcetin rhamnoside (Ferracane et al., 2010). The constituents of burdock exhibited antimicrobial properties (Gentil et al., 2006), had protective effect on oxidation of lipids and prevented the oxidative stress (Wang et al., 2006) as well as expressed anti-inflammatory properties (Zhao et al., 2009).

Many empirical relations describing the sorption characteristics of foods and food ingredients have been proposed in the literature (Al-Muhtaseb et al., 2002). The GAB equation is the general model for predicting the sorption isotherm for the most product including herbs (Kouhila et al., 2002; Červenka, 2008). The monolayer moisture content, a key parameter corresponding to the physical and chemical stability of foods, can be derived from this model. Other models such as Halsey (Halsey, 1948), Oswin (Oswin, 1946), Henderson (Igbeka and Blaisdell, 1982) and Peleg (Peleg, 1993) have been successfully applied to the sorption data of variety of dried products (Kouhila et al., 2001; Falade et al., 2003; Červenka et al., 2008; Červenka, 2009). For instance, GAB equation fitted well to the experimental sorption data of Eucalyptus globules whereas Hendereson’s equation predicted better the sorption behavior of mint, sage and verbena (Kouhila et al., 2001, 2002). In our recent work, Peleg’s equation fitted to the experimental data of black currant, black elderberry and chokeberry (Červenka, 2009); however, the parameters of this model lack physical meaning. For the purpose of optimizing the storage condition of various products, the sorption model with parameters, which can be easily applied to the practise, is a better choice. This situation represents the GAB equation with its monolayer moisture content. Similar equations have been proposed including Henderson’s model (Igbeka and Blaisdell, 1982) and Blahovec–Yanniotis model (Blahovec and Yanniotis, 2009). Henderson’s and Blahovec–Yanniotis equation allowed to distinguish between the amount of water bonded to the sorption site of nonsoluble solids and the amount of water presents in aqueous solution. The parameters of Blahovec–Yanniotis model (Table 2, equation (5)) were developed by substituting various parameters of Langmuir equation and Raoult’s law. Namely, parameter a1 and b1 are related to the kinetic of sorption in the first layer based on nonsoluble dry matter. Parameter a2 and b2 are related to the molar mass of water and nonsoluble dry matter (Yanniotis and Blahovec, 2009).

In the recent years, the concepts related to the aw have been enriched by those of glass transition temperature (Tg). Glass transition temperature is defined as the temperature at which the material changes from the glassy to the rubbery state for a given heating rate. The food biopolymers are stable at glassy state where rotational mobility of molecules is restricted while changes may occur at or above Tg (Ross, 2001). Despite of the fact that Tg and sorption isotherms represent two distinct criteria, Sablani et al. (2007) proposed both concepts to be used for determination of food stability. Tg is product specific and is a function of moisture content (or water activity) of material. Glass transition temperature as a function of moisture content for some solid and high sugar content food have been reported (Perdomo et al., 2008; Sablani et al., 2009; Symaladevi et al., 2009; Tonon et al., 2009; Rao et al., 2010). To our knowledge, there are limited data related to the combination of moisture sorption and glass transition temperature concepts in medicinal herbs (Scopus database).

The objective of the present study was to determine the moisture sorption characteristics and the dependence of the glass transition temperature on the water activity of elecampe and burdock root samples. Combining both concepts, we try to obtain moisture content (or water activity) for safe storage and handling at ambient temperature.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p:
Chopped and pre-dried pieces of roots (approximate size 1.0 × 0.5 cm2) of elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.) were purchased in local supply. The proximate composition was determined according to AOAC procedures (AOAC, 2007): moisture content (method 920.36), ash content (method 942.05), ether extract (method 932.02) and crude protein (method 2001.11). Initial water activity was measured using thermoconstanter Novasina aw Sprint (TH500, Axair Ltd., Switzerland). The total carbohydrate content was calculated from the difference. All the measurements were done in triplicate in two consecutive trials. The results are summarized in Table 1. Table 1.
Proximate chemical composition of elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.)
Elecampe Burdock
(mean ± SD, n = 6)
Ash (g/100 g d.b.) 2.23 ± 0.11 2.91 ± 0.25
Crude protein (N × 6.25) (g/100 g d.b.) 3.27 ± 0.83 4.60 ± 2.98
Ether extract (g/100 g d.b.) 0.54 ± 0.03 0.08 ± 0.01
Total carbohydrate1 (g/100 g d.b.) 36.88 33.21
1
Calculated by difference.

For the sorption study, the samples were pre-dried in forced-air oven at 50 °C for 24 h, and then the roots were manually grinded in a mortar and sieved to give particle size of <1.0 mm. The milled samples were subsequently dried over silica gel to the weight constancy.

sec.title: Determination of moisture sorption isotherm
sec.p: For the sorption studies, following salt slurries with known relative humidity (in %) at 25 °C were prepared according to Stoloff (1978): LiCl (11.3), CH3COOK (22.5), MgCl2 (32.8), K2CO3 (43.2), Mg (NO3)2 (52.9), CoCl2 (64.9), NaCl (75.3), KCl (84.3) and KNO3 (93.6). Moisture adsorption isotherms were determined gravimetrically by exposing dry root samples at 25 °C to different salt slurries. Approximately 1.0 g amounts of the dried sample were spread on aluminium pans and put into desiccators above appropriate salt slurry. A few crystals of thymol were placed in desiccators with relative humidity higher than 75% to prevent mould growth. After 2–3 weeks, the samples were gradually withdrawn and the true equilibrated water activity at 25 °C was measured in Novasina instrument. After measurement, the sample was immediately placed in forced-air oven and appropriate moisture content was determined according to AOAC procedure (method 920.36). For desorption process, the dry samples were placed above distilled water to adsorb moisture (up to 0.93 aw) to the weight constancy. The samples were then placed to the desiccators with various salt slurries. After 3–4 weeks, the water activity and the mass of each sample was measured. An analytical balance (sensitivity ± 0.001 g) was used for weighing of the samples. The results were expressed in g per 100 g of dry basis (d. b.). The isotherms were obtained by plotting the moisture content versus aw. Each isotherm was constructed using data of three replicates.

sec.title: Isotherm models
sec.p:
The experimental sorption data of two samples at 25 °C were fitted to six sorption equations (Table 2). The GAB equation (equation (1)) is the most versatile for various food products and biomaterials (Samaniego-Esguerra et al., 1991). The Peleg’s model (equation (4)) was applicable in the wide range of aw and was proposed as a standard model for cataloguing the sorption data of a large group of food and other biological materials (Peleg, 1993). Blahovec-Yanniotis (2009) introduced a four-parameter model based on the assumption that a part of the water is sorbed on nonsoluble solids forming a monolayer while the rest of the water is available as solvent for soluble solids (equation (5)). The amount of water bonded to the sorption sites of a nonsoluble solid is represented by the first term (aw/ (a1 + b1aw)) and the amount of water in a complex aqueous solution represents the second one (aw/ (a2 – b2aw)). Henderson’s equation (equation (6)) was applied in the linear form (Igbeka and Blaisdell, 1982). Table 2.
Sorption isotherm models used in this study
Model Equation
GAB (Samaniego- Esguerra et al., 1991)
(1)
Oswin (Oswin, 1946)
(2)
Halsey (Halsey, 1948)
(3)
Peleg (Peleg, 1993)
(4)
Blahovec-Yanniotis (Blahovec and Yanniotis, 2009)
(5)
Henderson (Igbeka and Blaisdell, 1982)
(6)

The parameters of the equations (equations (1) to (5)) were estimated using nonlinear regression technique (Gauss–Newton) in QCExpert™ v 3.0 (TriloByte s.r.o., Pardubice, Czech Republic). The goodness of fit was evaluated with the mean relative percentage deviation (%E) using formula (7)

Where Me are experimental and Mp are predicted moisture contents. A model is considered acceptable if the %E values are below 10% (Palou et al., 1997). The parameters of Henderson’s models were estimated by the least square method. The coefficient of determination (R2) represents the best-fit criterion in linear regression.

sec.title: Glass transition temperature
sec.p: The samples were adjusted to various water activities (0.113, 0.225, 0.328, 0.432, 0.529, 0649, 0.753 and 0.843) by adsorption process to the weight constancy. After the measurement of water activity, the glass transition temperature was immediately measured using differential scanning calorimeter (DSC 204 F1 Phoenix, Netzsch, Germany) equipped with an intracooler previously calibrated with indium. An amount of about 8.5 mg was hermetically sealed in aluminium pans. Each sample was cooled to −100 °C at 10 °C min−1 and the scanning was done by heating at the same rate from −100 °C to 100 °C with the empty aluminium pan as a reference. The glass transition temperature was determined from the midpoint of the heat capacity changes.
The glass transition temperature and moisture content relationship was modelled using Gordon–Taylor equation (Gordon and Taylor, 1952) (8)

Where Xs and Xw are the mass fraction of solid and water, respectively. Tg, Tgs, Tgw are the glass transition temperature of mixture, solids and water, respectively. Tgw = 138 K, where K is the Gordon-Taylor parameter.

sec.title: Moisture sorption isotherms
sec.p:
The results of the experimental measurements of the equilibrium moisture contents of elecampe and burdock at 25 °C are given in Figure 1(a) and (b), respectively. The shape of the isotherms is characteristic for high-sugar-containing foods which sorb relatively small amounts of water at low water activities and large amounts of moisture at high water activities, particularly above 0.75 aw. There is a clear difference in equilibrium moisture content above 0.55–0.60 aw where burdock sample has higher moisture content than elecampe. For instance, elecampe adsorbed moisture up to 35–37 g at the level of 0.80 aw, whereas burdock adsorbed moisture up to 52–55 g per 100 g of dry basis at the same level of aw. The proximate compositions revealed that elecampe had significantly higher content of lipophillic substances (p < 0.05), which may cause decrease in moisture adsorption (Bianco et al., 2001). A hysteresis effect at 25 °C was observed for both plant species involved in this study. The statistical comparison of the equilibrium moisture content at the same aw levels (paired t-test) revealed that elecampe and burdock showed hysteresis in the range of 0.35–0.90 aw (p < 0.001) (Figures 1(a)) and in the range of 0.65–0.80 aw (p < 0.001) (Figures 1(b)), respectively. Although this phenomenon was described in many food materials, the origin of its occurrence is poorly understood. Many empirical relationships have been published to describe the hysteresis in food material (Mathlouthi, 2001; Caurie, 2007; Yang et al., 1997). Caurie (2007) gave also explanation about the shape of the hysteresis loop which may be indicative of stability of food. The formation of micro-cracks and fissures in the adsorbent matrix due to cohesive forces and stress may occur when water is adsorbed. These micro-cracks and fissures exposed new energetic sites which adsorb moisture on return to lower aw rather than desorb moisture. Figure 1.
Sorption isotherm of (a) elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and (b) burdock (Arctium lappa L.) at 25 °C: (×) experimental values adsorption, (___) Blahovec–Yanniotis model fitting (adsorption); (▵) Experimental values-desorption; (- - -) Blahovec–Yanniotis model fitting (desorption).

sec.title: Isotherm models
sec.p:
Six isotherm equations (equations (1) to (6)) were used for establishing the degree of fit to the experimental data. Estimated parameters for equation (1) and equations (3) to (6) are presented in Table 3. Because Oswin’s model did not fit the experimental data well in burdock and elecampe root samples in both adsorption and desorption process (%E >10.0), the estimated parameters were excluded. GAB, Halsey, Blahovec–Yanniotis and Peleg’s models gave the %E values ranging from 1.344 to 0.727 for adsorption and from 1.670 to 6.796 for desorption processes. Applying two-way ANOVA test, Blahovec–Yanniotis equation gave the lowest average values of %E (p < 0.05) for both elecampe and burdock in desorption and adsorption processes. This equation (equation (5)) well described the sorption data of many food products including starchy and high protein foods, fruits and vegetables, nuts, legumes and seeds (Yanniotis and Blahovec, 2009). The advantage of this model over the GAB equation in fitting the experimental data is mainly on the high water activity. Therefore, it can be concluded that this model better described the sorption data of elecampe and burdock root samples in this study. Table 3.
Estimated parameters for selected models of adsorption and desorption isotherm equations for elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.) at 25°C

Blahovec-Yanniotis isotherm model (equation (5)).

sec.title: Properties of sorbed water
sec.p: The physical state of water in foods determines their stability during storage (Ross, 2001). Therefore, it is suitable to generate the information related to various aspects of water in food. The monolayer moisture contents of both root samples estimated from the GAB equation ranged from 8.61 to 10.28 g/100 g d. b. for burdock and 9.96 to 11.82 g/100 g d. b. for elecampe. It is evident that monolayer moisture contents were generally higher for burdock (p < 0.05) and was higher for desorption in contrast to adsorption process (p < 0.05). It is in agreement with the study of Kaymak-Ertekin and Gedik (2004) who determined higher M0 values in high sugar content fruits during desorption in comparison with adsorption process.

As was expected, more than one straight line could be fitted applying Henderson’s equation to experimental data. Theoretically, the Henderson’s isotherm should be divided into three local isotherms corresponding to monolayer, multilayer and free water content (Rockland, 1969). Thus the breaks in the curves indicate changes in the type of water binding. In our study, only one intersection point was observed (Figure 2(a) and (b)) representing the transition from multilayer state of sorbed water to mobile water, as was similarly reported for other food items (Červenka et al., 2008; Červenka, 2008). The breakpoints and corresponding moisture contents are presented in Table 3. For burdock, the isotherms intersected at moisture contents of 22.1 and 25.1 g/100 g d. b. for adsorption and desorption isotherm, respectively. Similar moisture content for elecampe was derived from Henderson´s equation (24.5 and 26.3 g/100 g, d. b. for adsorption and desorption, respectively). At higher values of moisture content, the water is considered to be unbound occurring in interstitial pores of food matrices (Rockland, 1969). Figure 2.
The predicted Henderson’s plot for (a) elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and (b) burdock (Arctia lappa L.) at 25°C: (⋄) adsoption; (▵) desorption.

Blahovec and Yanniotis presented different approach to moisture sorption behavior in food systems (Blahovec and Yanniotis, 2009; Yanniotis and Blahovec, 2009). Using their mathematical model, one can analyze the contribution of tightly adsorbed water and solution water in the sample. The contribution of bonded water was calculated for six aw levels using the term aw/(a1 + b1aw) of Blahovec–Yanniotis equation with parameters a1 and b1 shown in Table 3. The contribution of solution water was similarly calculated applying the second term of Equation (5), i.e. aw/ (a2−b2aw), with parameters a2 and b2 presented in Table 3. It is clear (Figures 3(a) and (b)) that the contribution of solution water is small in low water activities but at higher aw values (>0.60) the contribution is significant. The moisture tightly adsorbed on the sorption sites of burdock and elecampe root samples was in the range from 7.80 to 16.8 and from 7.90 to 11.50 g/100 g d. b., respectively. It is interesting to note that during adsorption process the amount of bound water slightly increased, i.e. the difference of equilibrium moisture content between 0.1 and 0.85 aw level was 3.6 and 8.9 g/100 g d. b. for elecampe and burdock, respectively. Smaller differences were determined during desorption process, i.e. 0.2 and 2.3 g of moisture per 100 g in dry basis for elecampe and burdock, respectively. We may hypothesize that some additional hydrophilic groups could unfold during adsorption process. Figure 3.
Contribution of the surface sorption and the solution in the adsorption and desorption isotherm of (a) elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and (b) burdock (Arctia lappa L.) at 25°C according to Blahovec–Yanniotis equation (equation (5)): (⋄) bonder water in adsorption; (⧫) solution water in adsorption; (○) bonder water in desorption; (•) solution water in desorption.

It is clear from the results described above that monolayer moisture content, M0 (equation (1)) fit to the interval of moisture contents adsorbed to the surface of sample as derived from Blahovec–Yanniotis model (equation (5)). The safe moisture contents obtained from Henderson’s model were higher than those obtained from GAB model, as we reported in our previous study (Červenka, 2008).

sec.title: Glass transition temperature
sec.p:
The effect of moisture content on glass transition temperature is shown in Figure 4. Glass transition temperature was found to vary with moisture content for both root samples. The decrease with an increase in moisture content was reported in many sugar-rich food including jaggery granules (Polamarasetty et al., 2010), spray dried açai juice (Tonon et al., 2009), raspberry (Symaladevi et al., 2009), cassava starch (Perdomo et al., 2008) or rice (Sablani et al., 2009). Although the glass transition temperatures for burdock are lower than those obtained for elecampe in the range of 0.1–0.8 aw, the difference in Tgs is only 3 K. It has been reported that low molecular weight compounds in carbohydrate mixture significantly reduced glass transition temperature. For instance, cassava starch supplemented with 6% of sodium chloride showed significantly lower Tgs value in comparison with cassava starch alone (Farahnaky et al., 2009). Schaller-Povolny et al. (2000) determined the effect of molecular weight of various maltodextrins on the glass transition temperature of inulin and found that glass transition properties is directly related to the average chain length. Figure 4.
The Gordon–Taylor model (equation (8)) to predict Tg as function of water activity for elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.). (⋄) Inula helenium experimental values; (__) Inula helenium predicted line; (•) Arctium lappa L. experimental values; (- - -) Arctium lappa L. predicted line.

The Gordon–Taylor equation has been successfully used for prediction of Tg for both root samples. The parameters estimated by nonlinear regression are shown in Table 4. Experimental data of Tg well fitted to the Gordon–Taylor model showing satisfactory values of R2 and E. The parameters K obtained from Gordon–Taylor were 0.125 and 0.341 for elecampe and burdock, respectively. This parameter can be related to the strength of interaction between the system components (Gordon and Taylor, 1952). Table 4.
Values used in prediction of Tg for Gordon–Taylor equation (equation (7))
Parameter Elecampe (Inula helenium L.) Burdock (Arctium lappa L.)
Tg s (K) 313.025 310.000
K 0.125 0.341
R2 0.931 0.981
%E 1.283 0.815

Combining the glass transition temperature concept with sorption isotherm is useful tool for estimation of critical values for aw and moisture content. According to Roos (1993), such a critical value is defined as those decreasing the Tg to ambient temperature. For estimation of critical moisture content for burdock and elecampe root samples, the adsorption isotherm using Blahovec–Yanniotis equation and the plot of Tg versus aw was constructed (Figure 5(a) and (b)). Applying the adsorption model, the critical moisture contents at 25 °C were evaluated to be 12.01 and 14.96 g/100 g d. b. for burdock and elecampe root samples, respectively. The corresponding critical aw values were 0.180 and 0.429, respectively (Table 5, Figure 5(a) and (b)). This means that burdock root sample stored at 25 °C can be exposed to the atmosphere up to 18.0% of relative humidity reaching the safe moisture content 12.01 g/100 g d. b. On the other hand, elecampe root should be stored up to 42.9% of relative humidity and its moisture content reach similar value of 14.96 g/100 g d. b. Table 5.
Comparison of water sorption isotherm and glass transition concepts for elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and burdock (Arctium lappa L.)
Sorption isotherm model Glass transition model
Temperature (°C) M0 (equation 1) (g/100 g, d. b.) aw monolayer water content Tg glass transition model (°C) Tg (°C) Water content (g/100 g d. b.) aw water activity
Elecampe 25 8.61 0.098 37.6 25 14.96 0.429
Burdock 25 9.96 0.129 28.6 25 12.01 0.180
Figure 5.
Water sorption isotherms and glass transition temperatures of (a) elecampe (Inula helenium L.) and (b) burdock (Arctium lappa L.) as function of water activity. (- - - - -) Glass transition temperature vs water activity (Gordon–Taylor model); (__) water activity vs equilibrium moisture content (Blahovec–Yanniotis model).

It was previously published that there is a surprising discrepancy between the prediction of stable temperature using sorption isotherm and glass transition concepts (Sablani et al., 2007). For example, Symaladevi et al. (2009) found that glass transition concept underestimated the stability temperatures for freeze-dried raspberries. The opposite effect was found in our work, where the sorption isotherm model increased Tg values to 28.6 and 37.6°C for burdock and elecampe, respectively (Figure 5, dotted arrows). On the other hand, the study of Zimeri and Kokini (2002) supported the results obtained in this study. They found that one type of native inulin (Raftiline) had monolayer moisture content 7.22% at 25°C and the corresponding Tg can be estimated in the range of 60–70°C. Moreover, they also concluded that glass transition temperature of inulin depended on the crystallinity, which is the function of moisture content. Detail study on physicochemical changes of polysaccharides or phenolic compounds at a range of water contents may better elucidate the suitability of moisture sorption isotherm or glass transition temperature concepts to predict stability of root samples.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Blahovec–Yanniotis fits well to the experimental data for both root samples. It was found that root samples of burdock; adsorbed significantly large amount of moisture at high water activity, probably due to lower content of lipophilic substances. In addition, sorption hysteresis was determined for both root samples. GAB, Blahovec–Yanniotis and Henderson’s equations have been used for determination of the extent of bound moisture. It was found that bonded water predominated up to 0.60 aw, whereas solution water contributed to the sorption isotherm at high water activity levels. The glass transition was determined in 14.96 and 12.01 g moisture/100 g d. b. for elecampe and burdock, respectively. The combination of Gordon–Taylor and GAB equations into one plot revealed that there is a discrepancy between predicting the Tg values. The glass transition temperature concept overestimated the temperature stability for both root samples.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Financial help for this project was provided by Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports of the Czech Republic (project No. 0021627502) and Czech Science Foundation (no. 203/08/1536).

def.p: equilibrium moisture content, experimental and predicted values, respectively (g/100 g dry basis)
monolayer moisture content in equation (1) (g/100 g dry basis)
mass fraction of solids and water, respectively (equation 8)
glass transition temperature of mixture, solids and water, respectively (equation 8)
